thread.title: North East's NHS 'could lose hundreds of staff over extreme Brexit'

author: Katie Dickinson
title: North East's NHS 'could lose hundreds of staff over extreme Brexit'
text:
News North East's NHS 'could lose hundreds of staff over extreme Brexit' The region could lose more than 500 staff members and face a £4.4m bill to replace them, the Liberal Democrats have claimed Share Hospital staff (Photo: Western Mail) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! The North East’s NHS could lose more than 500 staff members and face a £4.4m bill to replace them if Theresa May’s “extreme Brexit” goes ahead, the Liberal Democrats have claimed. 
A survey by the General Medical Council (GMC) in February found that 42% of nurses and more than half (56%) of all doctors from the EU were considering leaving the UK because of Brexit. 
This could mean the loss of an estimated 177 NHS staff members in Newcastle, including 112 doctors and nurses. 
The Lib Dems say this would create a £1.1m bill for Newcastle hospitals to re-hire doctors and nurses from the EU after 2019, due to Theresa May’s plans for a £2,000 immigration skills charge for each doctor, nurse and health worker brought in from abroad. A doctor with a baby and its mother (Photo: handout) 
The Liberal Democrats have called for an immediate guarantee that all EU nationals in the UK, including those working in the NHS and social care, can stay after Brexit. 
Across the North East, the survey indicates that more than 500 staff members are who qualified in European Economic Area (EEA) countries are considering leaving in the wake of Brexit - costing a total of £4,370,000 to rehire. 
Lib Dem candidate for Newcastle East, Dr Wendy Taylor, said: “Hospitals in Newcastle depend on doctors, nurses and other support staff from the EU. But many are now planning to leave because of the uncertainty caused by Brexit. Read More 
“We must guarantee their rights to stay here immediately to prevent a damaging exodus of these skilled and hard-working people. Our NHS, and the care we all rely on, would suffer without them.” Liberal Democrat candidate for Newcastle East Dr Wendy Taylor with NHS colleagues 
Dr Taylor, who is a consultant at the Freeman Hospital, added: “The NHS is far too precious to be damaged by Theresa May’s decision to pursue a UKIP-style Brexit. 
“The Liberal Democrats stand up to Theresa May’s extreme Brexit and give the people the final say, with the choice to remain in the European Union if they don’t like the deal on offer.” Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now 
In March the British Medical Association’s (BMA) North East chair, Dr George Rae, also called on the Government to grant permanent residency to EU doctors working in the region, saying Brexit would have a “calamitous” effect on our NHS services if their future was not assured. 
The focal point of the Conservative manifesto revolves around continued commitment to the NHS and an increase of spending. Read More Brexit will be 'calamitous' for the North East's NHS if EU doctors leave, senior medic warns 
Two years ago, Mrs May’s party pledged to spend a minimum of £8bn in real terms over the next five years and the manifesto says this is still the case.
